item.title: Instructions: May 11
item.author: shawn.graham@carleton.ca (Dr. Shawn Graham)
item.description: Goals for this week how to describe what’s gone wrong, and to figure out how to fix it Listen Read Do Try to work through as many of these exercises as you can. Don’t worry too much if you get stuck: the point is to push yourself beyond your current level of ability. Download and install the Sublime Text Editor Install Conda Download web materials with wget Use OCR (Object Character Recognition) to turn images of text into text Learn how to transform a text file using Regular Expressions Bonus:

item.title: Wget

item.description: Downloading web materials with wget Wget - can include jpgs

item.title: This week's bonus
item.author: shawn.graham@carleton.ca (Dr. Shawn Graham)
item.description: Historian’s don’t deal with video very well. That is to say, we don’t have many tools for dealing with video as video, as a moving image, and analyzing with an eye towards the specific affordances of the medium (but see Arnold and Tilton’s ‘Distant Viewing’ project, and their position paper.) But we’re good with text. In this bonus exercise, you’ll download a video from youtube of Dr. Martin Luther King’s ‘I have a dream’ speech (wikipedia), and use Google’s speech-to-text engine to generate a time-stamped transcript of the speech.
